clues.text:
1997 for biography:
This late author's "Angela's Ashes"

1978:
This late language lover for his New York Times commentary

1945 for music:
This composer for his "Appalachian Spring"

2006 for public service in covering Hurricane Katrina:
Mississippi's Sun-Herald & this New Orleans paper

1940 for drama:
This playwright's "The Time of Your Life"
In 2008 this strikeout king became president of the Texas Rangers ballclub
Since the mid-1990s she received a record 57 perfect 6.0 scores in major figure skating competitions
On Nov. 25, 1980 Sugar Ray Leonard reclaimed his welterweight title when this champ told the ref, "No mas, no mas"
This Steelers quarterback was the last player to win back-to-back Super Bowl MVP awards, in 1979 & 1980

The first African
American in the Tennis Hall of Fame, she was also the first to play on the LPGA tour, in 1963
His siblings are River, Rain, Liberty & Summer
Temperamental but talented baseball pitcher Joaquin Andujar hails from this Caribbean nation
The San Joaquin River flows through the San Joaquin Valley & joins with the Sacramento before reaching this bay
Responsible for economic & monetary affairs, Joaquin Almunia is a prominent official in the EC, this organization
It was the surname of Cuban-born composer Joaquin & his writer-daughter Anais
"My doctor said" to take this liquid antacid from Johnson & Johnson
It's the real first name of "60 Minutes" reporter Mike Wallace
It's a trade name for biaxially oriented polyethylene terephthalate
This white fatty material insulates brain nerves in sheaths & enables enhanced transmission of impulses
Agamemnon was from this region that was an important center in ancient Greece

rounds.comments: (Alex: Oh, gosh.  Joaquin my baby back home.  All right.  The writers are having fun.)

clues.text: In 1979 the exiled Ayatollah Khomeni made a triumphant return to this country after 14 years of exile
There was much rejoicing in 2005 as taikonauts from this country returned from space
The man known as the Lockerbie Bomber stirred emotions when he returned to this, his native country, in 2009
Gen. Wainwright surrendered Corregidor as commander of U.S. forces in this country, but came home a hero
In 2000 Nawaz Sharif was forced out of this country where he'd been prime minister; in 2007 he came back
To combat malnutrition, in 1942 Tasmanian blue peas were added to the rations of this country's troops
A Civil War song popular with Confederate troops celebrated goober peas, another name for these
Pea soup was a staple in the ships of this navy that beat the French & Spanish at Trafalgar
During the Revolutionary War, Congress passed a resolution making peas a part of this army's rations
In the 1940s General Mills produced dried peas for these "alphabetical" (& infamous) army rations
Bob Hope grew up in Cleveland, Ohio but was born in this country
In April 1961 he played with John Lee Hooker at Gerde's Folk City in New York
The onscreen & offscreen antics of this "Hogan's Heroes" star inspired the 2002 film "Auto Focus"
Known as "Bullet Bob", he won Olympic gold & a Super Bowl ring
Grilled pizza is a favorite dish of this host of the Food Network's "Hot Off The Grill"
Soothing lotion meant to be applied to the face following a trimming of your stubble
Alliterative sudsing powder added to your tub water
In the early '60s this "directional" brand introduced aerosol deodorant
"Chilly" name for a mineral oil compound used to remove cosmetics & soothe the skin
It's the removal of stray hairs by coating with hot paraffin & stripping it off when cooled
In the Middle East, the 992-foot Kingdom Center is this country's tallest building
The world's largest-capacity office building is this 29-acre structure outside Washington, D.C.
From street level you have to look up 86 floors to observe this NYC landmark's observation deck
Called a "Dzong", a fortified one of these religious residences often serves as an admin. center for regions of Bhutan
Hollywood's American Cinematheque is based at this theater built during the 1920s King Tut craze
Underground tombs often used to hide the dead
A sequence of numbers or letters that opens a lock
Someone walking on the sands hunting for curious objects
A rooster's crest
9-letter word for a tool used to groom a horse
The part of a pear with the seeds
In astronomy the barycenter is the center of mass of 2 bodies, usually one doing this in relation to the other
Your cells are eukaryotic, from the Greek for "nut", meaning they have a true one of these
In "Journey to the Center of the Earth", this "great fish lizard" kills a Plesiosaurus in savage combat
10-letter term for the structure of the universe as explained by Ptolemy of Alexandria
Mrs. Ben Affleck
Mrs. Keith Urban
Mrs. Freddie Prinze Jr.
Mrs. William H. Macy
Mrs. Josh Brolin

rounds.text: Widely parodied today, this 5-word phrase originally appeared on motivational posters in England during WWII
